User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:5.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/5.0
Build ID: 20110622105328

Steps to reproduce:

Set /bin/sh as a symbolic link to /bin/dash (normally points to /bin/bash).  Reboot system (boots fine).  Now start Firefox.

(Note:  above steps on Fedora 15 installation.)


Actual results:

Firefox won't start.  When run from command line, you get:

[: 76: /usr/lib64: unexpected operator
/usr/bin/firefox: 195: Syntax error: "(" unexpected (expecting "fi")

and it returns error code 2.


Expected results:

Firefox should start.

Reason #1:  line 76 uses "if [ string1 == string2 ]; then" which should be "if [ string1 = string2 ]; then" for compatibility with /usr/bin/test (bash usually overrides [ and test with shell internals, but other sh-compatible shells will not).

Reason #2:  line 195 defines a function, which is allowed in bash but not part of sh.

Solution:  First line of script should read "#! /bin/bash", not "#! /bin/sh".
